etymologies: Old English fether, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch veer and German Feder, from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit patra ‘wing’, Latin penna ‘feather’, and Greek pteron, pterux ‘wing’

definitions: any of the flat appendages growing from a bird's skin and forming its plumage, consisting of a partly hollow horny shaft fringed with vanes of barbs

examples.text: the waxwing has very bright feathers and a prominent crest
Sally-Anne, dolled up in ostrich feathers and pearls

definitions: one of the feathers or featherlike vanes fastened to the shaft of an arrow or a dart.
shortDefinitions: one of feathers or featherlike vanes fastened to shaft of arrow

definitions: a fringe of long hair on the legs of a dog, horse, or other animal.
shortDefinitions: fringe of hair on legs of animal

definitions: rotate the blades of (a propeller) about their own axes in such a way as to lessen the air or water resistance.
shortDefinitions: rotate propeller blades about own axes

definitions: vary the angle of attack of (rotor blades).
shortDefinitions: vary angle of attack of rotor blades

definitions: turn (an oar) so that it passes through the air edgewise

examples.text: he turned, feathering one oar slowly

shortDefinitions: turn oar to pass through air edgeways

definitions: float, move, or wave like a feather

examples.text: the green fronds feathered against a blue sky

shortDefinitions: touch person or thing very lightly

definitions: (of ink, lipstick, etc.) separate into tiny lines after application

examples.text: the ink started to feather and smudge
don't you just hate it when you spot that your lipstick has feathered around your lips?

shortDefinitions: separate into tiny lines after application

definitions: shorten or taper the hair by cutting or trimming

examples.text: my sister had her hair feathered
